lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Look at this test table that stores students and their grades. We'd like to know how many students got each of A, B, and C.

lessons.title: Intro 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
We could use COUNT(grade) and a condition like grade = 'A'. But this would only count students that got the grade A.

Make sure to pick grade, followed by WHERE, and finally grade = 'A'.

lessons.title: Intro 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
To count how many students got each grade, we use GROUP BY. This groups our results by the different grade values.

Make sure to type GROUP BY.

lessons.title: Select the whole column
lessons.interactiveContent:
When selecting the grade column, we have three different grades: A, B, and C, but four table rows because of the duplicate A.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by grade.

lessons.title: Grouping
lessons.interactiveContent:
By grouping the previous results by grade, we get three categories corresponding to the unique values A, B, and C.

Make sure to pick GROUP, followed by BY, and finally grade.

lessons.title: Counting
lessons.interactiveContent:
To find out how many students got each grade, start by using COUNT(*) to count entries in the table.

Make sure to type COUNT(*).

lessons.title: Question: Intro 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query do?

It counts users having the country 'England'It counts users from each country

It counts users having the country 'England'.

lessons.title: Question: Intro 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does GROUP BY in this query do?

It groups user items by their value in the country columnIt groups the values in the country column

It groups user items by their value in the country column.

lessons.title: Question: Grouping
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which categories do we get if we use GROUP BY country?

Two, England and SpainThree, one for each country value

Two, England and Spain.

lessons.title: Question: Counting
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the result of this query?

3, because we have three items2, because we have two columns

3, because we have three items.

lessons.title: Example: Counting
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use COUNT(*) to count the entries in this table.

Make sure to type COUNT(*).

lessons.title: Grouping the count results
lessons.interactiveContent:
We saw that the total count is 4. To see how many of these entries have A, or B, or C, we can group the count by grade.

Make sure to type grade.

lessons.title: Understanding the result
lessons.interactiveContent:
Before we move on, take a look at the table and the result below. What might the values in the COUNT(*) column stand for?

How many times each grade appears in the table, like 2 of AHow many different grade values we have

How many times each grade appears in the table, like 2 of A.

lessons.title: Select the categories
lessons.interactiveContent:
To better understand the results, let's select the grade categories we previously mentioned.

Make sure to pick grade, followed by ,.

lessons.title: Aliasing COUNT
lessons.interactiveContent:
Since each item describes a student and their grade, we're counting students. Rename COUNT(*) to students.

Make sure to pick AS, followed by students.

lessons.title: Query exaplanation
lessons.interactiveContent:
This query counts the table items, then uses GROUP BY to split the total count into the distinct grade categories.

Make sure to type GROUP BY.

lessons.title: GROUP BY and aggregate functions
lessons.interactiveContent:
We mainly use GROUP BY with aggregate functions, like AVG(), SUM(), or COUNT() like in our example.

Make sure to pick COUNT followed by ( and then *, ).

lessons.title: Question: Grouping the count results
lessons.interactiveContent:
What property could we group by to see how many users we have from each country?

countryemail

Make sure to pick country.

lessons.title: Question: Query exaplanation
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query do?

It breaks down the user count between the country groupsIt counts all user items in the table

It breaks down the user count between the country groups.

lessons.title: Question: GROUP BY and aggregate functio
lessons.interactiveContent:
When is GROUP BY useful?

When using aggregate functions, like AVG() or SUM()When having a table with only numeric properties

When using aggregate functions, like AVG() or SUM().

lessons.title: Example: Grouping the count results
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use GROUP BY to split the user count by country.

Make sure to type GROUP BY country.

lessons.title: Example: Select the categories
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the country column to see the country group next to the user count. Don't forget the comma ,.

Make sure to type country,.

lessons.title: Example: Aliasing COUNT
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use AS to rename COUNT(*) to users.

Make sure to type AS users.

lessons.title: Example: Query exaplanation
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the countries users are from and count users from each country.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by country, and then COUNT(*) AS users, GROUP BY country.

lessons.title: HAVING
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we're not interested in all groups and we'd like to filter some out, we can use HAVING.

Make sure to type HAVING.

lessons.title: Filtering groups 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
HAVING is like a WHERE for groups. We're only selecting those groups having a students count over 1.

Make sure to type HAVING.

lessons.title: Filtering groups 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Before, we excluded groups based on their COUNT(*) value. But we can also exclude them based on their grade value.

Make sure to type grade.

lessons.title: Filtering groups 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
In this query, we're counting how many students got each grade, but we omit the results for the grade 'A'.

Make sure to pick grade, followed by <>, and finally 'A'.

lessons.title: What to filter by
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use any selected property to build the condition in HAVING, like using grade or students here.

Make sure to pick students, followed by students.

lessons.title: Question: HAVING
lessons.interactiveContent:
When do we use GROUP BY together with HAVING?

When filtering out certain groupsWhen filtering out certain items

When filtering out certain groups.

lessons.title: Question: Filtering groups 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Can we use WHERE instead of HAVING to filter groups?

No, we can only use HAVINGYes, they're interchangeable

No, we can only use HAVING.

lessons.title: Question: Filtering groups 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which groups does this query select?

Only country groups that start with the letter EOnly columns that start with the letter E

Only country groups that start with the letter E.

lessons.title: Question: Filtering groups 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which groups does this query select?

country groups that have exactly one useruser items with country equal to 1

country groups that have exactly one user.

lessons.title: Question: What to filter by
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which properties can we use to filter the groups in this query?

country or COUNT(*) under the alias usersOnly COUNT(*)

country or COUNT(*) under the alias users.

lessons.title: Example: HAVING
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code HAVING before the condition, to only count users from 'Spain'.

Make sure to type HAVING.

lessons.title: Example: Filtering groups 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use HAVING and the alias users to select groups that have a COUNT(*) equal to 2.

Make sure to type HAVING users = 2.
